T=

When you, e.g. place an order, you send an order document wit=
h the details you intend the business transaction to be like (items + price=
). You'd rather not simply refer to some recipient-owned conversational sta=
te.

Thinking about it, I guess the real explanation is that the server-sid=
e state we are talking about e.g. the cart, is state the client has built u=
p while proceeding through the application (Roy called this workspace state=
 a while ago). In the discussed scenarios we are talking about workspace st=
ate that is persistet on the server. Doing so is RESTful (because the state=
 has a URI instead of being session state) but since it is workspace state =
you should obtain its current representation first and include that in your=
 POST instead of referring to it.

Does that help?

Another thing to consid=
er is that HTTP (not REST[1]) is restricted to a single request target URI[=
2]. Referring to the, e.g. cart URI, smells like two request target URIs to=
 me: tell the server to GET the cart and apply it's state to the POST execu=
tion. 

Jan
